intro: Hosackia pilosa, commonly known as the hairy false indigo, is a perennial herb native to the central and eastern United States. It is characterized by its hairy, upright stems and palmately divided, trifoliate leaves. The plant produces showy, violet-blue flowers in racemes during the summer months. It thrives in full sun to partial shade and prefers well-drained soils. Hosackia pilosa is often found in prairies, open woods, and along roadsides, contributing to the ecological diversity of these habitats.
